newsitem.title: USA: White House, Congress agree on banking legislation.
newsitem.headline: White House, Congress agree on banking legislation.

text.p: General agreement was reached Friday on banking measures to deal with remnants of the savings and loan crisis, with final action hinged upon a spending bill being crafted in Congress.

The Administration and Congressional Republicans worked out a compromise overnight on measures intended to ease regulatory burdens on banks which had been holding up the rest of the banking legislation.
The banking provisions are now expected to be added into a catch-all appropriations bill which is still being worked out.
The cornerstone of the banking legislation is a provision to beef up the Savings Association Insurance Fund (SAIF), which insures deposits at thrifts.
That fund has been undercapitalized because much of the premiums paid by thrifts are diverted to make the $793 million annual interest payments on Financing Corp. (FICO) bonds.
Those bonds were issued in the late 1980s to help with the clean-up of hundreds of failed savings and loans.
The legislation would require thrifts to pay a one-time charge totaling $4.7 billion to boost the SAIF to its required level, and then banks would share the FICO interest payments.
